title: What's it like writing a book after having written one before? - Quora

response.answer_text: That’s a very good question. I’m anxious to know what other authors will say so I’m choosing to follow this question. I don’t know how it is for others but, for me it gets more challenging each time. I have an uncontrollable impulse to try to make each book better than the last — more compelling plot, more compelling characters, more subject matter likely to appeal to readers, better spelling, better grammar, fewer uncaught mistakes when pressing “publish.” Sometimes I paint myself into the virtual “writer’s corner” by making so many demands on myself that it becomes impossible to proceed and I stall out in writer’s block. For this reason each of my books (full length epics averaging 200,000 words) takes longer to finish than the last. Some authors must not have this problem because I see some have published hundreds of books. I have two favorite authors, both geniuses in my opinion — Stephen King and Tom Robbins. King has hundreds of books while Robbins, who has apparently retired from writing, has fewer than a dozen. I see in Robbins’ writing an obsession with perfection, similar to mine while executed much better (his writing tends to be free of mistakes). King’s published works are full of problems, plot mistakes, mistakes in geography, misspelling, grammatical mistakes, and many more. And yet King is as much of a superb teller of compelling stories as Robbins and someone who inspires me just as much. So I can’t justify my obsession with perfection. It is what it is. Thanks for the curiosity.

It’s the best feeling! Once I’ve written one book, I’m more empowered to write another one. And as soon as others begin to read the previous book, it provides validation for future work. No matter how much I write, there’s always a bit of fear, but it becomes easier to push that fear aside the more I write. When I first began writing, 10 years ago, I had no idea how much time and effort is put into writing a book. I wonder if I had known back then, if I still would have pursued writing. And yet, I can’t stop now. LOL Dawn http://www.dawhusted.com & A Wordy Woman's Guide
